Druid.name: Druid
Druid.description:
While he was still stationed in Johannesburg, James Niakat worked alone on numerous secret projects. Over the years, the scientist was exhausted by his long days and especially by his inability to succeed in all his projects. Unable to stop his work, the genius then devised a way to duplicate himself or rather to create multiple bodies, controllable by simple thoughts. Through humanoid robotic interfaces, James Niakat imagined being able to work faster in his many laboratories and on his equally numerous projects. While the design of the robotic interfaces was easy, the control system was not, and the genius failed to develop it effectively. The robots would fall, were unable to perform precise tasks, and could not be controlled for long. Niakat thus shelved the idea and abandoned it.

It was Gauvain, who stumbled upon Merlin's notes, who revived the project to develop it. In certain parts of the globe, during certain missions, the knights of Avalon, being outnumbered, particularly need reinforcements or additional units, simply to manage crowds, escape from a fight where they are outnumbered, or perform complex operations requiring the concentration of many people. It is in this sense that Gauvain rethought James Niakat's project. He imagined armour capable of generating robotic allies, 'companions,' who could handle simple situations or support the knight in combat. In Gauvain's idea, it is not the knight who directly controls his doubles, but the armour's AI. The man in the machine could thus fight, and his AI could do the same while directly aiding the other knights in combat.

The Druid meta-armour was thus born, along with Avalon's first robotic allies. Controlled directly by the AI, they were named companions, and Gauvain designed them to have graceful and artistic animal features, so they could be easily identified by the knights and appreciated by civilians.



The Druid meta-armour is a third-generation meta-armour, resistant and designed for combat. It possesses an Infinity energy reactor and an AI that is among the most advanced in the organization, capable of making decisions and literally reading the mind of its wearer to anticipate their will. As a result, the AI and the knight bond even more than usual, becoming friends, close, and sometimes even developing a form of love, similar to that of Arthur and Guinevere.

With a simple thought, a knight in Druid armour can generate one or more companions that serve as bodies for his AI. These companions are made of nanoC projected from the right gauntlet of the meta-armour and can be of three different types: a solo type named Lion, a trio named Wolf, and a swarm named Crow. Each generated companion takes a portion of the meta-armour's energy to power its structure and modules. Regardless of its type, the AI can always communicate with its wearer and also with the outside world through a voice synthesizer.

The Lion type is the most common. It is a robotic humanoid body with slots in which modules chosen by the knight and his AI are equipped. It measures over two and a half meters, has a massive, asexual, and powerful body, as well as a 'face' sculpted into a stylized lion's maw. On the companion's body, the knight can have engravers from the arsenal apply engravings, symbols, and of course, colors.

The Wolf type consists of three small humanoid companions, measuring about one and a half meters and having faces similar to stylized wolf maws. Agile, precise, equipped with technical or medical gear, they are capable of helping the knight accomplish complex tasks but are not equipped to lead a fight on their own. They can, however, support a knight by distracting the target or creating a diversion.

Finally, the swarm named Crow is composed of about thirty small flying robotic units, capable of launching electrical discharges at enemies using their own energy. The Crow swarm is generally used to contain or slow down enemy crowds while the knight retreats.

Thanks to these different types of companions, the Druid meta-armour is a versatile tool. It is worth noting that, following the excellent results obtained by the knights in Druid armour and their companions on various Avalon operation theaters, Gauvain is studying the possibility of adding companions to each of the created meta-armours.
Druid.companionsDescription:
The Druid meta-armour is capable of generating three different types of companions. Only one type can be generated at a time and only in the manner presented below. Two or three types of companions cannot be created simultaneously during the same scene or phase of conflict; only one type can exist at a time. When the knight generates a companion, he deploys nanomachines from the palm of his gauntlet, which materialize into one or more robotic allies.

Each type of companion lasts for the duration of a scene or phase of conflict. To extend the 'life' of a type of companion into the next scene or phase of conflict, the knight must spend half the PE he would normally spend. Activation costs 6 seconds, or a full turn. Deactivating a companion costs neither PE nor action.

If a knight wishes to change the type of companion while one type is already present, he must again pay the normal cost in PE and use the standard activation of the mod. The present companion falls into nanomachine slag as another is created, with its PA and PE at maximum.

In all cases, if the PA (or cohesion) of the created type of companion falls to zero, it is destroyed. A new type of companion can be created for a normal energy cost.

The ignore armour effect has no effect on the companion's PA; damage is applied normally. Additionally, it ignores all domination and fear X type abilities.

Companions can never move away from the Druid meta-armour wearer by a distance greater than the long range. If a companion exceeds this distance, it falls into nanomachine slag and is considered destroyed.

Companions act on their initiative; the knight needs no action to make them act.

Finally, companions can receive the benefits provided by nods and all appropriate abilities. Their PE recharge in the same way as those of the knights, and they can recover PA by being repaired, thanks to abilities or nods.

Companion Generation

When the knight creates a type of companion, he must decide to grant it a minimum of PE from his own energy core. To do this, he must choose to temporarily lower his total PE by 10, 20, 30, 40, or 50 points. His current PE are reduced by the number of total PE sacrificed. Note that a knight cannot sacrifice more PE from his total than he currently possesses.

These points are sacrificed as long as the type of companion is present and form the companion's total PE as well as its current PE. To use its modules, the type of companion must spend these PE.

When the companion is destroyed or when it disappears, the knight recovers his total PE, and his current PE are increased to the level that the companion had at its destruction.
Druid.companionsDuration: One scene or one conflict phase
Druid.sCEvolutionsDruidDuration: One scene or one conflict phase
